It could be read 'apus' as well, but after observing the paleographical pattern of the other script 'ya', then the reading ‘ya’ makes more sense. , brata:

ni sib adumoṇa kapan mapuṅguṁ ya ka:lan· vvaṅṅ ana: bhavahika glәm anaya-naya, śastra gla:ṙ brata:ji vinija:-vija:h apa jamujit·, yapva ginә raṣaniṅ aji tahya paya murukutut·, lviṙ kadi bhaṅśapatrapati:ty avdi karuhunana phala tkap ta mamriḥhana kula sḍaṁ ta rare, yan apa
ya tan katoliha vuvusnira saṁ mahatuha, lvәha ttika: ya tesyana kabeḥ tikanaṁ śapakon·, Avitanaṁ riṁ pisan pva satahu nda L̥hәṁṅa tika śalat laṅśәb· poḥ naṅka raṣa linviḥ ṅka śiṅ amanis·, kaśevan kopadyan R̥ṣi mutih·, godha kuhara, Aśi santa:k karunya

yan· vimaṙgga giṇavai, masiḥ sireṁṅ agatti saṙvvajanma ṅuniveḥ mr̥ghaṅśarajani tambaḥ roṇḍon lata mvaṁ kakayu-kayu vaneḥ riṁ gunuṁ vvitika doḥ, siṁ vvit pinriḥ pinet ṣaṁ vruh i paknanika paṅhiṁlaṁ roga doḥnya, maṅka saṁ vruḥ vnaṁ paṇḍita śaraṇnaniki saṙvvajanma śi

kte boga bvat paL̥-paL̥h alupa riṁ pavkasaṅ atuha, nīdra: paruṣya ṅvaṁ daṙpaṅ anamaya kuraṅana sinkuṅ iṅayu, lobantomvaṁ tr̥ṣṇa thambәḥ ya ṅusira śuka piduvәgaṇa taṅ avak·, ragantag mәta:kriddhi ṅvaṁṅ uluy anakbini ya ta kita L̥L̥b· yeka ta: saṁ vruḥ mәgәp apuṁguṁ
